title: Birth of Samson
shortSummary: Judges chapter 13 recounts the miraculous announcement and birth of Samson, a Nazirite set apart by God to begin delivering Israel from Philistine oppression. The chapter highlights God's sovereign intervention through an angelic messenger and the faith and obedience of Manoah and his wife. This chapter sets the stage for Samson's role as a judge and deliverer of Israel.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges

keyCharacters.name: Manoah
keyCharacters.description: A Danite from Zorah, husband of Samson's mother, who seeks understanding and guidance about the angel's message concerning his son.

keyCharacters.name: Manoah's wife
keyCharacters.description: The barren woman who receives a divine visitation from the angel of the LORD and is instructed about her son's Nazirite vow.

keyCharacters.name: Angel of the LORD
keyCharacters.description: The divine messenger who announces Samson's birth and gives instructions for his upbringing as a Nazirite.

keyCharacters.name: Samson
keyCharacters.description: The promised son who will be a Nazirite from birth and begin to deliver Israel from the Philistines.

definitions.definition: A person consecrated to God by a special vow involving abstaining from wine, strong drink, unclean foods, and cutting hair, symbolizing dedication to God.
A divine messenger who represents God’s presence and authority, often speaking with God's own voice.
Refers to foods or practices forbidden by the Mosaic Law, emphasizing ritual purity.
A sacrificial offering wholly consumed by fire on the altar, symbolizing atonement and dedication to God.

outline.heading: Israel’s Oppression and Manoah’s Family
outline.description: Israel again does evil, resulting in 40 years of Philistine oppression. Introduction of Manoah and his barren wife, setting the stage for God’s intervention.

outline.heading: Divine Announcement to Manoah’s Wife
outline.description: The angel of the LORD appears to Manoah’s wife, announcing she will bear a son dedicated as a Nazirite who will deliver Israel.

outline.heading: Manoah’s Prayer and Angel’s Second Visit
outline.description: Manoah prays for guidance; the angel returns to reiterate the Nazirite instructions and the importance of obedience.

outline.heading: Offerings and Revelation of the Angel’s Identity
outline.description: Manoah offers a sacrifice; the angel ascends in the flame, revealing his divine nature and confirming the message.

outline.heading: Response of Manoah and His Wife and Birth of Samson
outline.description: Manoah fears death for seeing God’s angel, but his wife reassures him. Their son Samson is born and blessed by the LORD, with the Spirit beginning to move him.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign plans even when circumstances seem impossible, as seen in the barrenness of Manoah’s wife.
Obedience to God’s instructions is essential, especially in dedicating our lives to Him as Samson was set apart as a Nazirite.
Seek God in prayer for wisdom and guidance when facing uncertainty, following Manoah’s example.
Recognize and honor God’s divine messengers and revelations, responding with reverence and faith.

keyVerses.text: For, lo, thou shalt conceive, and bear a son; and no razor shall come on his head: for the child shall be a Nazarite unto God from the womb: and he shall begin to deliver Israel out of the hand of the Philistines.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Samson’s divine calling and Nazirite vow, highlighting God’s plan to use him as a deliverer.

keyVerses.text: And the woman bare a son, and called his name Samson: and the child grew, and the LORD blessed him.
keyVerses.significance: The fulfillment of God’s promise, showing His faithfulness and blessing on Samson’s life.

keyVerses.text: And the Spirit of the LORD began to move him at times in the camp of Dan between Zorah and Eshtaol.
keyVerses.significance: Indicates the empowering presence of God’s Spirit upon Samson, enabling him for his future role.
